Award.AwardTitle: Catalyst Project: Biological Experiences Strengthen Talent through Interdisciplinary (BEST IN) Forensic and Investigative Genomics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. Through this catalyst project, Prairie View A&M University will initiate a comprehensive and synergetic forensic genomics program which will broaden awareness and access to the STEM workforce by engaging students in innovative interdisciplinary educational activities. The program will impact society by increasing minority representation and advancement in the forensic science workforce.

The proposed activities will advance knowledge and understanding within the field of Forensic Science as well as across multiple disciplines, both STEM and non-STEM at PVAMU and the surrounding educational communities. By enhancing the scientific exposure of students, they will graduate with a more well-rounded training that can improve competitiveness in the STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Catalyst Project: Biological Experiences Strengthen Talent through INterdisciplinary (BEST IN) Forensic and Investigative Genomics project at Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) broadened awareness and access to the STEM workforce by engaging students in innovative interdisciplinary educational activities that interfaced forensic science and genomics. The overall goal of the project was to improve the quality of undergraduate STEM education, increase the number of students pursuing STEM degrees and provide evidence-based recommendations by tracking and analyzing the BEST IN Forensic and Investigative Genomics project's effect.  

Intellectual Merit: In an age of genomic advances that impact many aspects of society, educating students about genomic technologies as well as the ethical, legal, and social implications of genomics is an urgent necessity to produce a scientifically literate student population prepared for future genomic developments and applications. The project outcomes included: 1) establishing an interdisciplinary teaching team to implement STEM and humanities-based student experiences relevant for a broad understanding of forensic genomics and 2) developing an Interdisciplinary Forensic Science Certificate Program.  Approximately 100 students enrolled in biology courses that implemented genetic genealogy. The courses addressed comprehensive genealogy analysis that included the use of DNA testing in combination with traditional genealogy research to infer ancestral relationships and legal implications.  The project's activities captured student interest, strengthen student engagement in learning STEM concepts, and address ethical, legal, and social issues in forensic genomics. Workshops and seminars were also implemented for students to explore STEM career opportunities.  

Broader Impacts: The project addressed diversity disparities in the STEM Workforce. To increase minority representation and advancement in the forensic science workforce, an Interdisciplinary Forensic Science Certificate Program was developed that followed the accreditation standards established by the American Academy of Forensic Science (AAFS) via the Forensic Science Education Programs Accreditation Commission (FEPAC). The project strengthened the quality of undergraduate academic curriculum through a targeted infusion of inquiry-based experiences.
